audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker inquiring about the "fastest woman in the world" and predicting varying answers, highlighting the hard work of these women. The speaker then shifts to Florence Griffith Joyner, also known as Flo Jo, as a long established female in the world of sprinting, referencing the 100 meters and 200 meters records that have remained since 1988. Throughout this narration, there is background music with a casual and relaxing tone.

The audio features a male speaker in a declarative tone discussing FloJo's athletic achievements, highlighting her Olympic wins and world championships. He mentions she started running at age seven, developed an interest in sports and fashion, and convinced her teammates to pair long tights with their track uniforms. The speaker notes that she became a media celebrity with her decorated fingernails and racing suits, concluding with her quote: "Dress good to look good, look good to feel good, and feel good to run fast" referring to her on-track fashion statements. A sound effect resembling twinkling or sparkling sounds plays in the background.

A male speaker with a lively and enthusiastic tone describes Florence Griffith Joyner's career, mentioning her rededication to the sport, marriage to Al Joyner, name change, and nickname "FloJo". He concludes by stating she "made history in the sport" and asserts that this information is widely known. A triumphant-sounding musical piece plays in the background throughout the monologue.

The clip starts with a male speaker describing the US Olympic trials in 1988, where Griffith Joyner achieved a breakthrough by running the 100 meters in 10.49 seconds and breaking Evelyn Ashford's record. The speaker mentions she competed in the Seoul Olympics, breaking records in the 100 and 200-meter races and winning medals in relay races. The tone is informative and somewhat excited.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker setting the stage by talking about Florence Griffith Joyner, or Flo Jo, and her unbeatable record. He sounds engaged and informative. He continues by adding that this brings him to his next point.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing an athlete close to breaking a record. He mentions Sha'Carri Richardson, and says some refer to her as "the new fastest woman on Earth," referencing a performance at the World Athletics Championships in Budapest. The audio concludes with the male speaker referring to the location of the event.

The audio begins with a narrator describing a sports event, specifically a race, noting a record-breaking time, and highlighting achievements, such as being the fifth fastest woman over a certain distance. The tone is informative and excited, emphasizing the significance of the athlete's performance. The narrator emphasizes the athlete's unprecedented performance. Concluding the sentence in an excited tone.

The audio clip features a single male speaker reporting sports news. He first notes that "Richardson turns out to be the first American 100-meter world champion in six years," adding that "the late Tori Bowie was the last US sprinter to bring home the 100-meter gold." Then he emphasizes that "Shakari went home with not one, not two, but three medals," detailing her achievements with both gold and bronze medals. The speaker maintains a clear, informative tone throughout.

The clip opens with a single, confident male speaker detailing Richardson's recent Jackie Joyner-Kersee award and accomplishments at the World Athletics Championships, highlighting her as the first woman in years to win the award for the 100 meters event. He then transitions to discussing how many athletes are working hard to break world records.

The audio clip features a male speaker discussing a famous Jamaican trio, suggesting they could potentially break FloJo's records. The speaker notes that other competitors exist globally, before directing the focus back to the Jamaican athletes. The tone is informative and slightly enthusiastic.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing Elaine Thompson-Herah's season best, followed by contrasting information about Shelly-Ann Fraser Price's performance at the World Championships, stating that she "made some history, just not the sort she was hoping for," earning her a bronze medal, and concluding that it's still "a good addition to her already amazing collection of medals." The tone is informative and narrative.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing Sharika Jackson, mentioning her role as the "queen of the 200 meters." He notes her undefeated streak in the half-lap sprint and mentions her retaining her world title and approaching the world record. The speaker references her silver medal in the 100 meters in Budapest and her women's 200 meter title. He describes her start in lane six, her lead going into the bend, and her time of 21.41, which broke her own championship record. The speaker maintains an informative tone throughout this description.

The clip features a single male speaker, who highlights several athletes with the potential to beat Flo Jo's records, clarifying that others could be contenders too. He speaks in a confident, informative tone. He concludes by suggesting that the records could be broken in Paris.
